message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms indicate a possible diagnosis of gonorrhea, which is commonly treated with ceftriaxone IM and doxycycline orally. Option A, Ampicillin, is not effective against gonorrhea. Gentamicin and Streptomycin are both antibiotics used for the treatment of tuberculosis and are not effective against gonorrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and sexual history suggest that the patient has gonorrhea, which is treated with Ceftriaxone IM and Doxycycline orally. Ampicillin is not effective against gonorrhea, and Gentamicin and Streptomycin are not used to treat gonorrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a diagnosis of gonorrhea. Ceftriaxone, an injectable antibiotic, is the first-line treatment for gonorrhea. Doxycycline is an oral antibiotic that is often prescribed as a secondary treatment for gonorrhea. Ampicillin is not commonly used to treat gonorrhea, and gentamicin and streptomycin are not effective against gonorrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible gonorrhea infection, for which ceftriaxone is the first-line IM treatment. Doxycycline is usually prescribed as a complementary oral medication to treat possible concurrent chlamydia infection. Ampicillin, gentamicin, and streptomycin are not effective against gonorrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a sexually transmitted infection, and ceftriaxone IM is commonly used to treat gonorrhea. Doxycycline is the preferred oral medication for concurrent chlamydia infection, which often occurs with gonorrhea. Ampicillin, Gentamicin, and Streptomycin are not commonly used to treat gonorrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the risk factors suggest that the patient has gonorrhea, which is treated with Ceftriaxone IM and Doxycycline orally. The other options are not typically used to treat gonorrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and sexual history suggest a sexually transmitted infection, specifically gonorrhea. Ceftriaxone is usually given for the initial treatment of gonorrhea, followed by oral doxycycline to complete the treatment course. None of the other options are commonly used to treat gonorrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The yellowish watery discharge from the penis and painful urination suggest a sexually transmitted infection, most likely gonorrhea. Ceftriaxone IM is a recommended treatment for gonorrhea, and Doxycycline is commonly prescribed as an oral medication. Ampicillin, Gentamicin, and Streptomycin are not effective treatments for gonorrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and risk factors suggest that the patient has gonorrhea. The most commonly prescribed oral drug for gonorrhea is doxycycline. Ampicillin is not effective against gonorrhea, and gentamicin and streptomycin are given intravenously or intramuscularly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest that the patient may have gonorrhea, and ceftriaxone is a common treatment for gonorrhea. Doxycycline is often given as an accompanying oral medication, as it has activity against chlamydia, which is commonly co-infected with gonorrhea. Ampicillin, gentamicin, and streptomycin are not indicated for the treatment of gonorrhea.
